awd_titl_txt: Fast X-ray Microscopy to Quantify the Nucleation of Hot Cracking
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
 
This project will use state-of-the-art facilities for ultra-high speed imaging with high energy synchrotron x-rays for the purpose of understanding the problem of hot cracking during the solidification of metals and alloys. Hot cracking means that, instead of obtaining fully solid metal during casting or 3D printing, cracks are left behind that weaken the material.  It may also mean that the cracked component must be discarded and/or trimmed, which is wasteful.  The main focus will be on studying cracking during 3D printing with laser light where mega-Hertz imaging provides micro-second resolution of the sort best known for stop-action movies of bullets penetrating through armor. Such ultra-high speed imaging has made rapid progress in recent years thanks to the advent of new cameras and improvements in x-ray detection and has already made substantial contributions to our understanding of the melting process. It is thus extremely well suited to imaging the sudden onset and growth of cracks. The sensitivity of cracking to variations in solidification speed and chemical composition will be investigated. Computer simulation will be used to test hypotheses about how the cracking happens with respect to the materials microstructure. The new understanding gained in this work has broad impacts in the casting industry in general. It is also likely to stimulate new theoretical analysis of the problem, which often happens when a new experimental technique is applied. In addition to supporting a doctoral student, undergraduates will be recruited to assist with the work, which involves a good deal of detailed analysis of sequences of images. The work will also be disseminated to the twenty-plus companies that are members of CMU's NextManufacturing Center and have a strong direct interest in additive manufacturing. As the analysis proceeds, the main results will be incorporated into the PI's teaching, which will help ensure that CMU's MS and engineering minor programs in additive manufacturing stay up to date.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

This proposal will use ultra-fast x-ray microscopy, with the high energy, high intensity synchrotron x-rays, to test the hypothesis that the nucleation of solidification cracking is variable and depends on the morphology of the solid near the end of the freezing process. Given the lack of direct measurement of the nucleation point and the arbitrary aspect of nucleation in cracking theories, even a measurement of the solid fraction at which cracking starts will be novel. Measuring the degree to which the nucleation of cracking depends on the extent of columnar versus equiaxed growth will further extend our fundamental knowledge of the problem. We will also probe for heterogeneous nucleation of the cracks from, e.g., the small vapor bubbles that are often observed in laser melting of Al-based alloys. The expected results include direct visualization of solidification cracking in a variety of materials as a function of temperature gradient and cooling rate, which are controlled by laser power and scan speed. We will mainly focus on aluminum alloys, partly because many of the structural Al alloys are prone to cracking and partly for ease of imaging, with stainless steel or nickel alloys for comparison purposes. We will also use lattice-Boltzmann simulations (from a previous DMREF project) to model the solidification and quantify the mushy zone, specifically the shape of the liquid zones at high solid fractions. The most direct impact will be on laser powder bed printing but the potential for broader impact on casting technologies also exists. Through collaboration, we will seek access to different types of modified powders that are intended to avoid cracking through, e.g., promoting equiaxed microstructures. We will use computed tomography and sectioning for 3D characterization. The ultra-fast x-ray microscopy will be mostly carried out at the Advanced Photon Source because this facility has the best combination of high energy and intensity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The primary outcome of this project lies in our establishment of a quantitative framework designed to assess hot cracking susceptibility across diverse alloy systems. This overarching outcome is further delineated into six distinct components.
The initial component of our research centered on the direct experimental assessment of hot cracking morphology in ten distinct alloys, employing x-ray radiography. We quantified and compared the hot cracking susceptibility of these alloys, leading to the formulation of a comprehensive ranking dataset across multiple alloy systems. This dataset served as a crucial validation foundation for our correlational study on hot cracking susceptibility. The associated dataset was published in Data in Brief that supported the susceptibility index development noted below.
In the project’s second component, we introduced a hot cracking susceptibility index anchored on macroscopic parameters of a given alloy, encompassing its composition, density, and material toughness. The inherent measurability of these parameters facilitates the macroscopic assessment of an alloy's hot cracking susceptibility without extensive experimental characterization. Through our research, it became evident that the susceptibility of a material to hot cracking was predominantly influenced by its high-temperature toughness and alloy composition, while variations in material density during solidification have less impact. By integrating high-temperature toughness metrics into the prevailing hot cracking index found in literature, we arrived at a more versatile and resilient index, apt for predicting the hot cracking susceptibility of metal alloys. This methodology was subsequently published in Metallurgical & Materials Transactions A.
The project's third segment focused on 2D comprehensive simulations pertaining to the laser welding process and the resulting distribution of thermal strain. A systematic approach was established, based on a hybrid code that integrates the Lattice Boltzmann method and the cellular automaton model (LB-CA). This combination facilitated the extraction of thermal history and microstructural data of materials subjected to varied laser processing conditions. Harnessing this data, we expanded the approach to predict the distribution of strains induced thermally due to the process through the use of a spectral method for computing stress-strain response from images of the microstructure. Notably, our thermal simulations were in good agreement with our x-ray radiography observations. Moreover, the microstructure simulations executed via LB-CA mirrored the anticipated columnar grain growth within the fusion zone, in addition to the discernible texture variations induced by distinct thermal processing conditions. These findings resonated well with microstructural analyses prevalent in existing literature.
In the project's fourth component, we delved into the phenomenon of pressure depression at the onset of hot cracking initiation. Leveraging the data from thermal and microstructure simulations, as well as strain distribution information obtained in the preceding segment, we estimated the pressure depression across the grain boundary network within the fusion zone. This endeavor furnished a microscopic quantification of hot cracking susceptibility based on pressure depression metrics. Consequently, this enabled us to evaluate the spatial distribution of hot cracking susceptibility within the fusion zone, accentuating regions with elevated vulnerability to hot cracking. Intriguingly, our simulations unveiled disparities in hot cracking susceptibility as a function of the the laser processing parameters, a finding consistent with our x-ray diagnostic work.
The fifth phase explored the feasibility of employing beam control techniques to curtail defect formation during the laser melting process. Notably, we manipulated keyhole dynamics within the melt pool utilizing a high-speed oscillating mirror loaned to the Advanced Photon Source (at Argonne Natl. Lab.) by General Electric (Global Research). This innovative application enabled us to reduce the keyhole porosity often observed during laser melting under high-power, low-speed conditions. Such porosity is a precursor to hot cracking. Notwithstanding the successful synchrotron experiment to demonstrate control over the laser melting process, our endeavors to harness this technique for the direct mitigation of hot cracking formation have not borne conclusive outcomes to date. Our findings and methodologies were documented in the recent publication in Communication Materials. Additionally, this research phase paved the way for a successful proposal for beam time at the European Synchrotron Radiation Facility (ESRF), which took place in June 2023. This further fostered an active collaboration with a team working on beam shaping at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (LLNL).
The sixth segment of our research embarked on a data-centric approach to forecast hot cracking susceptibility within the Ni alloy and Al alloy groups. A pivotal breakthrough was realized as we incorporated thermodynamic data into the machine learning model training, enhancing the accuracy of prediction of hot cracking susceptibility across multiple alloy systems. Of the various machine learning models scrutinized, the Random Forest Regression emerged as the most effective, boasting an impressive R2 score of 0.85. This advancement establishes a robust foundation to support and inform alloy design endeavors in the future.  A manuscript is in preparation.


Last Modified: 01/01/2024
Modified by: Anthony D Rollett
